Influence of the structure and morphology of CuO supports on the amount and properties of copper–cerium interfacial sites in inverse CeO2/CuO catalysts Yueling Yin Kewei Liu Meiyi Gao Lu Zhang Haiquan Su Shanghong Zeng ⁎ Inner Mongolia Key Laboratory of Chemistry and Physics of Rare Earth Materials, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University, Hohhot 010021, PR China Inner Mongolia Key Laboratory of Chemistry and Physics of Rare Earth Materials School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Inner Mongolia University Hohhot 010021 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 471 8935112/60210; fax: +864714992981. Graphical abstract The CuO supports with different morphologies were prepared and the inverse CeO2/CuO catalysts were synthesized by the impregnation method. The catalysts were characterized via SEM, XRD, H2-TPR, in situ DRIFTS, XPS, TEM and N2 adsorption–desorption techniques. It is found that the CeO2/CuO-X catalysts present good catalytic performance in the CO–PROX reaction. Catalytic performance is related to BET specific surface area, Ce3+ content and reduction temperature of CuO. Cu+ species is CO adsorption site over the CeO2/CuO catalysts. The carbonate and hydrogen carbonate species cover the surface of CeO2/CuO catalysts at high temperature, and these species could cause the deactivation of the catalysts. The CuO particles are reduced into the metallic copper with large crystallite sizes after the reaction. The metallic copper is oxidized into CuO again, while the crystallite sizes of CeO2 and CuO both increase via regeneration. There are two possible ways to solve the problem of deactivation. One is to control the reaction temperature, and the other is to prevent the generation of metallic copper by promoting structure and morphology of the CuO support. Keywords Support morphology Cerium–copper catalysts Interfacial sites Deactivation Regeneration 1 Introduction The proton-exchanged membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) has been regarded as one of the most attractive power source for transport and portable applications [1,2]. The trace amounts of CO in the hydrogen stream need be removed in order to avoid poisoning Pt anodes. Preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX) is one of the most straightforward and efficient methods to achieve acceptable CO concentrations [3–6]. Thus, the highly efficient and selective catalysts are required to remove CO in the hydrogen-rich stream. Noble metal catalysts are highly active in CO–PROX reaction [1,4,7–9]. However, the high price and depletable resource have limited their applications. In particular, CuO/CeO2 catalysts have been widely studied for their high selectivity, durability and economy. For the mechanism of CO oxidation over CuO/CeO2 catalysts, the studies show that both CuO and CeO2 play important roles in the reaction and the reaction occurs at the contact interface of CuO and CeO2 [10–15]. In 2010, Hornés et al. [16] reported an inverse CeO2/CuO catalyst with wider CO conversion window and higher CO2 selectivity in comparison with the classical CuO/CeO2 catalyst, and the results are attributed to the maintenance of amount and properties of copper–cerium interfacial sites in this inverse system. It is generally recognized that CuO in the CuO–CeO2 catalysts serves as adsorption sites for CO [10,13,15,16]. It is inevitable for the CuO–CeO2 catalysts to occur the reduction of CuO in the hydrogen-rich stream. CO–PROX reaction strongly depends on properties of copper oxide such as oxidation state [17], crystallite size [12,18] composition and content [19–21]. There is still an open question: how to maintain amount and properties of copper-cerium interfacial sites in the inverse system? The reduction of CuO is closely associated with structure and morphology of CuO supports. Therefore, it is interesting and necessary to study the change of structure and morphology of CuO supports and its influence on performance in the hydrogen-rich stream. In this work, the CuO supports with different morphologies were prepared and the inverse CeO2/CuO catalysts were synthesized by the impregnation method. In our previous studies [22], it is found that the CeO2–CuO catalysts present the best performance when the molar ratio of Ce/Cu is 1/1. Thus, the molar ratio of Ce/Cu was selected as 1/1. In addition, the deactivation mechanism and regeneration also were studied for further applications of the CeO2/CuO catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The solvothermal method was used to prepare the CuO with cotton-ball-like morphology [23]. The Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O and urea with a 1:3 molar ratio were dissolved in 100ml ethylene glycol, and the solution was vigorously stirred at room temperature. Then the solution was transferred into a stainless steel autoclave and heated for 12h at 140°C. After cooling to room temperature naturally, the precipitate was washed with distilled water and absolute ethyl alcohol, respectively. Further, the precipitate was dried at 60°C for 24h, and then calcined at 400°C for 3h to obtain the CuO-A support. The hydrothermal method was used to prepare the CuO with microsphere morphology [24]. The 0.4M CuSO4 and 3M lactic acid were dissolved in 100ml distilled water, and the NaOH solution was added into the above solution. The mixture was vigorously stirred at room temperature. Then the solution were transferred into a stainless steel autoclave and heated for 16h at 120°C. The precipitate was washed with distilled water and dried at 80°C for 24h. Further, the precipitate was calcined at 400°C for 3h to obtain the CuO-B support. The precipitation method was used to prepare the CuO with flower-ball-like morphology [25]. The 3ml CuSO4 (0.4M) and 1ml NaOH (0.48M) were dissolved in 0.9ml ammonia solution, and the mixture was vigorously stirred at room temperature. Then the mixture was aged at 68°C for 24h. The precipitate was collected by centrifugation and filtration, and washed with distilled water. Further, the precipitate was dried at 80°C for 24h, and then calcined at 400°C for 3h to obtain the CuO-C support. The hydrothermal method was used to prepare the CuO with particle morphology [26]. The 10mM Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O and 12.5mM NaOH were dissolved in 18ml distilled water, and the mixture was vigorously stirred at room temperature. Then the solution was transferred into a stainless steel autoclave and heated for 12h at 140°C. The precipitate was washed with distilled water and dried at 60°C for 24h. Further, the precipitate was calcined at 400°C for 3h to obtain the CuO-D support. The as-prepared CuO supports were impregnated with Ce(NO3)3 aqueous solution by equal volume impregnation method (n CeO2:n CuO =1:1). After impregnation, the samples were dried at 80°C for 24h, and then calcined at 400°C for 3h in the air. The obtained catalysts were named as CeO2/CuO-X. The CeO2/CuO-X catalysts after the reaction were re-calcined in a muffle furnace at 400°C for 3h to get the re-calcination catalysts, which were marked as CeO2/CuO-X–R. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Scanning electron microscopy images of samples was taken on a Hitachi S-4800 scanning electron microscope, using secondary electrons to form the images. The samples were coated with a thin layer of Pt before scanning. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a PANalytical X’pert PRO diffractometer with Cu Kα source (λ =0.15406nm) and a power setting of 40kV and 100mA in the range of 2θ between 10°C and 80°C. The average crystallite sizes were estimated from the line broadening using the Scherrer’s equation. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained at liquid nitrogen temperature (−196°C) using a Micrometrics ASAP2020 adsorption apparatus. The samples were degassed under a vacuum of 10−5 Torr for 12h at 200°C prior to analysis. The surface area and pore size distribution were determined by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and the Barrette–Joynere–Halenda (BJH) methods, respectively. H2 temperature-programmed reduction was conducted on a Micromeritics Apparatus (AutoChem II 2920). The reduction gas was 10% H2/Ar gas mixture and the flow rate of gas was 50mlmin−1. The 30mg sample was placed on top of some silica wool in a quartz reactor. Before reduction, the sample was pretreated at 200°C for 1h in a N2 stream in order to remove the contaminants, and then cooled to room temperature. The H2/Ar mixture was switched on and the sample was heated with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. The reaction was performed from room temperature to 900°C. In situ DRIFTS analysis was performed on a Nicolet 6700 apparatus equipped with an MCT detector. Prior to measurement, the sample was pretreated at 300°C for 2h in a N2 stream. The feed stream containing 60% H2, 1% O2 and 1% CO in nitrogen was introduced into the infrared cell and the IR spectra were collected from 35°C to 215°C. The reaction spectra of the catalysts were subtracted from the background spectra at the corresponding temperature. X-ray photoelectron spectra were collected on a Thermo ESCALAB 250XI spectrometer with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (150W, 1486.6eV) for the analyses of the core level signals of O 1s, Cu 2p and Ce 3d. The spectra of samples were recorded with the constant pass energy values at 25eV, using a analysis area of 500μm diameter. Transmission electron microscopy images were taken on a FEI tecnai F20 transmission electron microscope. The sample was dispersed into ethanol with the ultrasonic treatment for 10min, and a drop of the suspension was placed on a copper grid for TEM observation. 2.3 Catalytic performance tests The catalytic performance tests were carried in a quartz reactor inserted in a furnace. The reaction mixture consisted of 1% CO, 1% O2 and 50% H2 (volume fraction) with N2 as balance gas. The space velocity was 40,000mlgcat −1 h−1. The reaction was operated between 35°C and 215°C. Product and reactant analyses were conducted by a GC-2014C gas chromatograph. A 5A molecular sieve column was used to separate CO, O2 and N2. CO2 was determined by a TDX column. Water was trapped before the gasses entered the GC. CO2 was absorbed before entering the 5A molecular sieve. The conversion of CO (C CO) and the selectivity for CO oxidation (Sco2) were calculated according to the following Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. (1) C CO = CO in − CO out CO in × 100 % (2) S CO 2 = 0 . 5 CO in − CO out O 2 i n − O 2 out × 100 % 3 Results 3.1 Scanning electron microscopy Fig. 1 shows SEM images of the as-prepared CuO supports. It can be observed that the preparation condition has a great influence on morphology and structure of the CuO supports. The CuO-A support presents three-dimensional, porous and cotton-ball-like structure. The CuO-B support is composed of the microspheres with about 5μm diameter. The CuO-C support consists of the CuO with flower-ball-like morphology. The CuO-D support is particle morphology, and the diameter of CuO particles is about 20nm. Fig. 2 shows SEM images of the CeO2/CuO-X catalysts, and Supplementary material 1 shows EDS mapping of the CeO2/CuO-X catalysts. The EDS results indicate that the CeO2 was homogeneously distributed in the catalysts, which was favorable for the increase of contact periphery between CeO2 and CuO on the interface. 3.2 X-ray powder diffraction Fig. 3 shows XRD patterns of the CeO2/CuO-X catalysts. The diffraction peaks at 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3° and 58.3° could be assigned to (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) planes of cubic fluorite CeO2 (JCPDS 65-5923). The intense diffraction peaks at 35.4° and 38.7° corresponded to (002) and (111) planes of monoclinic CuO (JCPDS 45-0937). It can be observed that the diffraction peaks of CeO2 are broad and the diffraction peaks of CuO are sharp, suggesting that the CeO2 was small crystallite size and CuO had high crystallinity. Table 1 lists the average crystallite sizes calculated by the Scherrer formula from line broadening of the diffraction peaks of CeO2 and CuO. The crystallite sizes of CeO2 are about 5–6nm and the crystallite sizes of CuO are from 17nm to 28nm. It can be seen that the crystallite sizes of CeO2 over the CeO2/CuO-C and CeO2/CuO-D are smaller than those over the CeO2/CuO-A and CeO2/CuO-B. Moreover, the crystallite sizes of CuO gradually decrease from CeO2/CuO-A to CeO2/CuO-D. Combined with the SEM images, it is evident that the crystallite sizes of CuO are closely associated with the sizes of CuO supports. From Table 1, it can be seen that the lattice parameter of CeO2 and CuO has no obvious difference for the as-prepared catalysts, suggesting that Cu2+ did not enter into the crystal lattice of CeO2 [27]. It is probably because the CuO had been prepared into the supports before loading CeO2. Fig. 4 shows XRD patterns of the used and re-calcined CeO2/CuO-X catalysts. After the CO–PROX reaction, the diffraction peaks of cubic fluorite CeO2 and metallic copper are detected and the diffraction peaks of CuO disappear in the used CeO2/CuO-X catalysts, indicating that most of the CuO was reduced into the metallic copper in the hydrogen-rich gasses. It can be observed that the diffraction peaks of monoclinic CuO appear again and the diffraction peaks of cubic fluorite CeO2 become sharp compared with the fresh CeO2/CuO-X catalysts after the re-calcination. Table 2 lists structural properties of the used and re-calcined CeO2/CuO-X catalysts. It can be seen that the Cu has big crystallite size in the CeO2/CuO-X-used catalysts, and the crystallite sizes are from 26nm to 52nm. After the re-calcination, the metallic copper is oxidized into CuO again, while the crystallite sizes of CeO2 and CuO both increase in comparison with the fresh catalysts. In addition, it can be observed that the lattice parameter of CeO2 has some change in the CeO2/CuO-X-used catalysts, which is closely related to the hydrogen-rich reaction atmosphere. However, the lattice parameter of CeO2 after the re-calcination becomes basically consistent with that of the fresh catalysts, suggesting that CeO2 had good storage and release capability of oxygen. 3.3 Nitrogen adsorption/desorption Fig. 5 shows N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of the CeO2/CuO-X catalysts. The isotherms are type-IV isotherms according to five kinds of isotherms from BDDT pore model, which is characteristic of mesoporous materials [28,29]. In addition, the narrow pore size distribution shows the presence of uniform pores in the catalysts [30]. It can be observed from Table 1 that the morphology of CuO supports had a certain influence on the BET specific surface area and pore volume. The CeO2/CuO-B and CeO2/CuO-C possess higher BET specific surface area than CeO2/CuO-A and CeO2/CuO-D, indicating that the catalysts using the microsphere and flower ball as supports easily got high BET specific surface area in the as-prepared samples. However, the CeO2/CuO-D has the biggest pore volume. It suggests that the particle CuO support might be favorable for the formation of micropores inside the catalyst. 3.4 H2-temperature programmed reduction Fig. 6 shows H2-TPR profiles of the CuO supports and the CeO2/CuO-X catalysts. For four supports, it can be observed that there is one overlapping reduction peak between 100°C and 500°C, which is composed of three reduction peaks (named as α, β and γ peaks). The α peak at low temperature corresponded to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO. The β (220–260°C) and γ peaks (above 260°C) were assigned to the reduction of medium-size and bulk CuO, respectively [31,32]. As shown in Fig. 6, the reduction peak of bulk CuO is weak in the profile of CuO-B, indicating that the microsphere-like CuO mainly consisted of the highly dispersed and medium-size CuO. Moreover, the reduction peak of bulk CuO appears at near 450°C for the CuO-C, which suggests that the bulk CuO in this catalyst was difficult to reduce compared with the other catalysts. For CeO2/CuO-X catalysts, the reduction peaks of CuO all shift to lower temperature in comparison to H2-TPR profiles of the CuO supports, suggesting that the presence of CeO2 improved the reduction of CuO. The reduction peaks at 450°C and 750°C were attributed to the reduction of surface and bulk ceria, respectively [31–34]. It can be observed that there is a strong reduction peak of surface ceria in the profile of the CeO2/CuO-C. In addition, the reduction peaks of bulk ceria all shift to lower temperature over the CeO2/CuO-A and CeO2/CuO-B catalysts. Fig. 7 shows H2-TPR profiles of the re-calcined CeO2/CuO-X catalysts. It is noteworthy that the intensities of α peaks decrease while the intensities of β and γ peaks increase in comparison with the fresh CeO2/CuO-X catalysts. In addition, the reduction peaks of CuO all shift to high temperature, indicating that the highly dispersed CuO transformed into the medium-size and bulk CuO. Compared with the fresh CeO2/CuO-X catalysts, the reduction peaks of surface ceria at 450°C become strong over the re-calcined CeO2/CuO-X catalysts, and the reduction peaks of bulk ceria all shift to high temperature over the CeO2/CuO-A–R and CeO2/CuO-B–R catalysts. It indicates that the CeO2 was re-dispersed on the surface of CuO supports to produce more surface CeO2. Moreover, the particle sizes of CuO and CeO2 increase in the re-calcined CeO2/CuO-X catalysts, and it is accordant with the analyses of X-ray powder diffraction. 3.5 Catalytic performance tests The catalytic performance of CeO2/CuO-X catalysts was evaluated in the CO-PROX reaction from 35°C to 215°C, using a synthetic gas (1% CO, 1% O2, 50% H2 and N2 balance). Fig. 8 shows CO conversion and selectivity toward CO2 over the CeO2/CuO-X catalysts. It can be observed that the performance is very similar for the as-prepared catalysts. The CO conversion increases with the increase of reaction temperature until the reaction temperature reaches 155°C. Above 155°C, the CO conversion begins to decrease with further increase of reaction temperature because of the H2 competitive oxidation. In contrast, the CeO2 supported on flower-ball-like CuO (CeO2/CuO-C) possesses the widest temperature window of total CO conversion (135–175°C), which is closely associated with the reduction of CuO, as mentioned in the TPR analyses. Above 155°C, the CeO2/CuO-A and CeO2/CuO-C present better high-temperature activity and selectivity among four samples. In addition, the CeO2 supported on particle CuO (CeO2/CuO-D) has weakest selectivity for CO oxidation because of small particle size. It suggests that the structure and morphology of CuO supports had certain influence on the catalytic performance in the PROX reaction. 3.6 In situ DRIFTS analyses Fig. 9 shows in situ DRIFTS spectra of the CeO2/CuO-C and CeO2/CuO-D catalysts. The bottom spectrum was obtained at 35°C, and the above spectra were collected from 55°C to 215°C in steps of 20°C (from bottom to top). There are three main spectral zones including 3800–2800cm−1, 2400–2000cm−1 and 2000–1000cm−1. The region between 3800 and 2800cm−1 mostly displays the bands related to hydroxyl species of various types. The narrow bands between 3720 and 3500cm−1 corresponded to isolated hydroxyls (mono-coordinated or poly-coordinated to surface cerium cations). The wide bands extending between 3800 and 3000cm−1 were attributed to associated hydroxyl species affected by H-bond interactions or the vibrations of surface hydroxyl [35,36]. It can be observed that the bands of associated hydroxyl species appear with increasing temperature over the CeO2/CuO-C, suggesting the presence of H2 and CO competitive oxidation in the CO–PROX reaction. The bands at 2914.9 and 2854.1cm−1 (CeO2/CuO-C) as well as at 2915.1 and 2852cm−1 (CeO2/CuO-D) were assigned to formate species [37–39]. The generation of formate species could be interrelated to onset of the WGS reaction [38,39]. The performance tests show that the WGS reaction does not take place between 35°C and 215°C. The generation of formate species could be due to the -OH groups on the catalyst surface, which reacted with CO to produce formate species. For CeO2/CuO-D, the wide bands from 3650 and 3000cm−1 appear at low temperature and become stronger and stronger with increasing temperature, indicating that H2 oxidation began at lower temperature compared with CeO2/CuO-C. Therefore, as shown in Fig. 8, the CeO2/CuO-D has lower selectivity than the CeO2/CuO-C because H2 oxidation is the main competitive reaction for CO oxidation [40–42]. The bands in the 2400–2300cm−1 range indicate the formation of CO2. The formation of CO2 resulted from the interaction between CO and Cu2+ ions with unsaturated coordination or the interaction between CO and Cu+-carbonyl species produced by CO adsorption on reduction centers [39]. The multiple bands in the 2200–2000cm−1 range reveal that there is a spontaneous variation in the extent reduction of CeO2/CuO at room temperature [11]. The bands between 2130 and 2100cm−1 were attributed to Cu+-carbonyl species, which increases with increasing the temperature below 115°C and then decreases with further increasing the temperature above 115°C. Until 215°C, Cu+ species still exists in the CeO2/CuO catalysts, indicating that Cu+ species was CO adsorption site over the CeO2/CuO catalysts. In the 2000–1000cm−1 region, the bands at 1254.5cm−1 and 1396.2cm−1 for the CeO2/CuO-C catalyst were assigned to mono- or tri-dentate carbonate species, while the band at 1467.6cm−1 corresponded to hydrogen carbonate species [36,37]. For the CeO2/CuO-D catalyst, the bands at 1643.0cm−1 and 1334.5cm−1 were attributed to bidentate or monodentate carbonate species, and the peak at 1397.2cm−1 was assigned to hydroxyl carbonate groups [35,36,43]. As shown in Fig. 9, the bands of carbonate and hydrogen carbonate species are dominant at high temperature, suggesting that the carbonate and hydrogen carbonate species covered the surface of CeO2/CuO catalysts. These species could cause the deactivation of the catalysts. 3.7 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS measurements were performed to further illuminate the chemical state of the elements and their relative abundance in the catalyst surface. Fig. 10 shows Ce 3d spectra of the fresh and re-calcined CeO2/CuO-X catalysts. The interpretation of the core levels of Ce 3d spectra are complex due to the hybridization between the Ce 4f levels and the O 2p states [18,44]. As shown in Fig. 10, The core levels of Ce 3d signals are decomposed into six peaks as ν 0, ν 1, ν 2 (Ce 3d 5/2) and ν 0′, ν 1′, ν 2′ (Ce 3d 3/2). Moreover, two peaks u 0 (Ce 3d 5/2) and u 0′ (Ce 3d 3/2) correspond to Ce4+ 3d and Ce3+ 3d states, respectively. The presence of Ce3+ was attributed to the interaction between ceria and the surrounding atoms. The interaction between CeO2 and CuO could lead to a transfer of lattice oxygen from CeO2 into CuO [45,46]. The ν 2′ peak at 915.3eV was characteristic of Ce4+, while the doublet u 0/u 0′ at 883.9 and 902.1eV was assigned to Ce3+ species. A favorable method which considers the relative intensity of the u′(v′) and u 0 (v 0) peaks to the intensity of Ce 3d region was applied to estimate Ce3+ content. It can be observed from Table 3 that Ce3+ content of the CeO2/CuO-C catalyst is higher than that of CeO2/CuO-D. The presence of Ce3+ is favorable for storage and transport of oxygen. Hence, the CeO2 supported on flower-ball-like CuO (CeO2/CuO-C) presents better performance in comparison with the CeO2 supported on particle CuO (CeO2/CuO-D), as shown in the Fig. 8. Ce 3 + ( % ) = S ( Ce 3 + ) S ( Ce 3 + + Ce 4 + ) = S ( u i ) + S ( u i ′ ) S ( u i ) + S ( u i ′ ) + S ( v i ) + S ( v i ′ ) × 100 % Fig. 11 shows Cu 2p photoelectron spectra of the fresh and re-calcined CeO2/CuO-X catalysts. The presence of shake-up peak, a higher Cu 2p3/2 binding energy (933.0–933.8eV) and 0.55 intensity ratio of the shake-up satellite to the corresponding principal peak are three major XPS characteristics of CuO, while a lower Cu 2p3/2 binding energy (932.2–933.1eV) and the absence of the shake-up peak are characteristics of the reduced copper species [18,40,45–47]. As shown in Fig. 11, the principal peaks of Cu 2p 3/2 are centered at about 933.0eV and the corresponding satellite peaks appear at 940–947eV. From Table 3, the intensity ratios of the shake-up satellite to the principal peaks are lower than 0.55 for the CeO2/CuO-C and CeO2/CuO-D catalysts, indicating that copper was composed of CuO and the reduced copper species in the above catalysts.Figs. 10 and 11 also show XPS spectra of the CeO2/CuO-C–R and CeO2/CuO-D–R catalysts. It can be observed that the shake-up peaks become weaker than the fresh catalysts after the re-calcination. As can be seen in Table 3, the I sat/I mp values of CeO2/CuO-C–R and CeO2/CuO-D–R catalysts are lower than those of the fresh catalysts, and it indicates that there were more reduced copper species in the CeO2/CuO-C–R and CeO2/CuO-D–R catalysts after the re-calcination. In addition, the Ce3+ content also has some change compared with the fresh catalysts, suggesting that the chemical state of the elements over the CeO2/CuO-C–R and CeO2/CuO-D–R catalysts was different from the fresh catalysts. Moreover, it can be observed from Table 3 that the Ce/Cu molar ratios from XPS measurements are higher than those calculated from the preparation condition, which indicates that the CeO2 particles were dispersed on the surface of CuO supports. It is evident that the Ce/Cu molar ratio of the CeO2/CuO-C is higher that of the CeO2/CuO-D on the catalyst surface, which was helpful for the interaction between CeO2 and CuO to improve the catalytic performance. After the re-calcination, the Ce/Cu molar ratios decrease over the CeO2/CuO-C–R and CeO2/CuO-D–R catalysts and it is closely associated with increase of the particle sizes of CuO and CeO2, as mentioned in the analyses of H2-temperature programmed reduction. 3.8 Transmission electron microscopy TEM measurements were carried out in order to further obtain intuitive morphologies of the fresh, used and re-calcined CeO2/CuO-C catalysts. Fig. 12 shows TEM images of the catalysts. For the fresh catalyst (Fig. 12A), it can be observed that the CeO2 particles gather into small clusters, which are dispersed on the bulk CuO. The contact interface exists between the CeO2 clusters and the bulk CuO particles. After the CO-PROX reaction, as shown in Fig. 12B, the crystallite sizes of CeO2 increase and the CuO particles in the interface are reduced into the metallic copper with large crystallite sizes. The metallic copper is covered on the outside surface of bulk CuO. Moreover, the metallic copper is converted into the CuO again after the re-calcination (Fig. 12C), and the crystallite sizes of CeO2 and CuO become big in comparison with the fresh CeO2/CuO-C catalyst, which is accordant with the analyses of XRD and TPR measurements. 4 Discussion Fig. 13 shows CO conversion and selectivity toward CO2 over the CeO2/CuO-X–R catalysts in the CO–PROX reaction. It can be observed that the re-calcined catalysts present poorer catalytic activity than the fresh catalysts, indicating that both of the chemical state and structure of the CeO2/CuO catalysts had certain change after catalyst regeneration. For CO–PROX reaction, its particularity lies in its hydrogen-rich reaction atmosphere, which leads to continuous change of catalyst because of occurrence of redox reaction during CO oxidation. However, this kind of change is favorable for CO oxidation over the CuO–CeO2 catalysts. This is why CuO–CeO2 catalyst has high activity and selectivity in the CO–PROX process and constitutes a more interesting alternative to noble metal catalysts. Now the question is if this change can be controlled to prevent the deactivation of the CuO–CeO2 catalyst? It is evident that temperature is a vital condition in CO–PROX reaction. Gold catalyst can realize CO oxidation at low temperature, but this condition limits the reactive rate. CuO–CeO2 catalyst is promising at work temperature of PEMFC (80∼200°C). As mentioned in the analyses of catalytic performance, the CO conversion begins to decrease above 155°C, which is closely associated with the reduction of CuO. The CeO2/CuO-C catalyst possesses the widest temperature window of total CO conversion (135–175°C) because TPR measurements show that the CuO is difficult to reduce compared with the other catalysts. How to prevent the reduction of CuO in the hydrogen-rich reaction atmosphere? It is clear that bulk CuO is helpful for the increase of reduction temperature of CuO. Even for CeO2/CuO-C, most of CuO is reduced into metallic copper after the reaction at 215°C, as can be seen in the XRD measurements. In addition, the particle sizes of CuO and CeO2 increase after catalyst regeneration. Therefore, there are two possible ways to solve the problem of deactivation. One is to control the reaction temperature, and the other is to prevent the generation of metallic copper by promoting structure and morphology of the CuO support. 5 Conclusions The CeO2 is distributed on the CuO supports with different morphologies by impregnation method. XRD measurements show that the CeO2 is small crystallite size and CuO has high crystallinity. Cu2+ does not enter into the crystal lattice of CeO2. Performance tests present that the CeO2 supported on flower-ball-like CuO (CeO2/CuO-C) possesses the widest temperature window of total CO conversion (135–175°C), which is closely associated with its high BET specific surface area, high reduction temperature of CuO and high Ce3+ content. In situ DRIFTS analyses display that Cu+ species was CO adsorption sites over the CeO2/CuO catalysts. The carbonate and hydrogen carbonate species cover the surface of CeO2/CuO catalysts at high temperature, and these species could cause the deactivation of the catalysts. XRD, TPR and TEM measurements show that the crystallite sizes of CeO2 increase and the CuO particles in the interface are reduced into the metallic copper with large crystallite sizes after the reaction. The metallic copper is covered on the outside surface of bulk CuO. After catalyst regeneration, the metallic copper is oxidized into CuO again, while the crystallite sizes of CeO2 and CuO both increase in comparison with the fresh catalysts, therefore, the re-calcined catalysts present poorer catalytic activity than the fresh catalysts. There are two possible ways to solve the problem of deactivation. One is to control the reaction temperature, and the other is to prevent the generation of metallic copper by promoting structure and morphology of the CuO support. coredata.dc:description: The CuO supports with different morphologies were prepared and the inverse CeO2/CuO catalysts were synthesized by the impregnation method. The catalysts were characterized via SEM, XRD, H2-TPR, in situ DRIFTS, XPS, TEM and N2 adsorption–desorption techniques. It is found that the CeO2/CuO-X catalysts present good catalytic performance in the CO–PROX reaction. Catalytic performance is related to BET specific surface area, Ce3+ content and reduction temperature of CuO. Cu+ species is CO adsorption site over the CeO2/CuO catalysts. The carbonate and hydrogen carbonate species cover the surface of CeO2/CuO catalysts at high temperature, and these species could cause the deactivation of the catalysts. The CuO particles are reduced into the metallic copper with large crystallite sizes after the reaction. The metallic copper is oxidized into CuO again, while the crystallite sizes of CeO2 and CuO both increase via regeneration. There are two possible ways to solve the problem of deactivation. One is to control the reaction temperature, and the other is to prevent the generation of metallic copper by promoting structure and morphology of the CuO support.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of the structure and morphology of CuO supports on the amount and properties of copper–cerium interfacial sites in inverse CeO2/CuO catalysts
